misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed starting at 1 (positions 1..N), so the first element is at index 1 and the last element is at index N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0..N-1. Using 1..N causes attempts to access index N (out of bounds) and skips index 0 entirely. This breaks input, shifting, and printing, and triggers runtime exceptions before producing the intended output.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException during input (and also later during shift/print for N>0).

evidence.code_snippet:
// I think arrays have elements from 1 to arraySizeInput, so I will start from 1
int arrayIndexCounter = 1;

// I think the last element is at position arraySizeInput
int lastElementTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[arraySizeInput];

// I think the elements go from 1 to arraySizeInput
int printIndexCounter = 1;

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are 1-indexed (elements numbered from 1 to N), similar to mathematical notation or some other programming languages. They think the first element is at position 1, not position 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are 0-indexed: valid indices range from 0 to length-1. The student consistently uses 1-based indexing throughout their code, which causes array accesses to skip the first element (index 0) and attempt to access an out-of-bounds element at index arraySizeInput, resulting in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when attempting to access userInputArray[arraySizeInput] during the shift operation, or incorrect values being read/printed if the exception doesn't occur

evidence.code_snippet:
// I think the last element is at position arraySizeInput
            int lastElementTemporaryHolder = userInputArray[arraySizeInput];

// Place the original last element at the first position (which I think is index 1)
            userInputArray[1] = lastElementTemporaryHolder;

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are 1-indexed, meaning that the first element is accessed at index 1 and the final element is accessed at an index equal to the array's declared size.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays utilize 0-based indexing. For an array of size N, the valid indices range from 0 to N-1. Indexing at N triggers an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, and index 0 is the standard starting position for data.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the loop condition for traversing an entire array should include the length of the array as a valid index (using <= length).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to recognize that the size used in array instantiation (N) is not a valid addressable index; the largest valid index is N-1.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed from 1 to N (where N is the entered size), so the first element should be stored at index 1 and the last element at index N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-based: valid indices are 0 through (length - 1). Using indices 1..N causes attempts to access index N, which is out of bounds, and also ignores index 0 entirely. This breaks both input storage, shifting logic, and printing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException during input (and also during shifting/printing if execution reached those parts).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array size equals last valid index (confusing length with max index)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if an array has size N, then index N is a valid location (i.e., the last element is at position N).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, for an array of length N, the last valid index is N-1. Treating N as a valid index leads to out-of-bounds access when reading the 'last element' and when assigning shifted values into index N.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when accessing userInputArray[arraySizeInput] or writing to userInputArray[shiftIndex] when shiftIndex == arraySizeInput.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are indexed from 1 to N (1-based), where position 1 holds the first element and position N holds the last element. They think of the array as having usable positions starting at 1, similar to mathematical or some non-programming contexts.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are 0-indexed, meaning valid indices range from 0 to (size - 1). An array of size N has indices [0, 1, 2, ..., N-1]. The student's code attempts to access index N, which is out of bounds and will cause an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. Additionally, index 0 is never populated with input data, remaining as 0 (the default value for int arrays).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when attempting to read the 4th element at line 24 where userInputArray[4] = currentInputValue is executed. The array has only indices 0-3, but the code tries to write to index 4.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array Size vs. Last Index Confusion
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the last element of an array of size N is located at index N. They treat the array size as if it directly corresponds to a valid index position.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: An array of size N has valid indices from 0 to N-1. The last element is at index N-1, not N. Using arraySizeInput as an array index is one position beyond the array's bounds. This directly causes the ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Attempt to access index 4 in a 4-element array (which only has indices 0, 1, 2, 3) results in ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices in Java start at 1 and end at the value of the array's size (N), rather than starting at 0 and ending at N-1.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays use zero-based indexing. An array declared with size N has valid indices ranging from 0 to N-1. Attempting to access index N results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
